turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Rumpler 6B.
turn.1: What are the main characteristics of the Rumpler 6B?
turn.2: Rumpler 6B The Rumpler 6B was a German single-engine floatplane fighter with a biplane wing structure, designed and built by Rumpler Flugzeugwerke, in Berlin Johannisthal and introduced in 1916.
turn.3: What is the origin of the design?
turn.4: Born out of a requirement of the "Kaiserliche Marine" (Imperial Navy) for a seaplane fighter, the Rumpler 6B was, like its contemporaries the Albatros W.4 and Hansa-Brandenburg W.9, an adaptation of an existing landplane design.
turn.6: In Rumpler's case the new floatplane fighter was based on the company's two-seat C.I reconnaissance aircraft. The modifications included adding a forward stagger to the wings, removal of the second (observer's) cockpit and fitting a larger rudder to offset the increased side area caused by the addition of floats.
turn.8: In the production aircraft, the area of the horizontal tail surfaces was also slightly reduced.
turn.10: The armament consisted of a fixed, forward-firing 7.92 mm (.312 in) LMG 08/15 "Spandau" machine gun mounted on port side of the engine block.
turn.12: The initial version of the fighter was the 6B1.
